content: 1 egap margot s garden fingerless mittens by karen porter sometimes winter seems to drag on forever and as the days begin to get longer it s impossible to keep from dreaming about warm spring days ahead as soon as the winter holidays are over i start dreaming about the garden i ll have this year i sketch out plans while i pore over seed catalogs and garden supply websites thinking about the lovely sharp smell of damp earth the luscious flavor of tomatoes still warm from the sun and the heavenly fragrance of flowers ahhh… it s lovely to dream of long warm days and growing things but even if the days are still cold and grey you can plant these little mitts with row of flowers to help remind you of gardens and long warm days to come size and gauge women s average 7 5 palm circumference at a gauge of 32 sts = 10cm/4in row gauge is not as important the size can most easily be adjusted by changing gauge/needle size and/or by choosing a slightly heavier or lighter weight of yarn because stranded colorwork does not stretch as much as solid-color knitting you will find these most comfortable if they have from ¼ negative ease to ½ positive ease based on your palm circumference above the thumb these mitts are relatively short if you d like a longer wrist just work an extra repeat of the flower pattern before beginning the thumb gusset materials fingering or sock weight yarn - main color mc 100 yd - green for leaves 25 yd - flower colors 12 yd for each row of flowers for both mitts 3 00mm needles for your preferred style of knitting small circumferences or size needed to achieve desired gauge i used double points for mine but they could easily be knit with magic loop or with two circulars i recommend double points for the thumbs stitch markers optional waste yarn for holding stitches tapestry needle for weaving in ends and embroidery a note on yarn shades and amounts i have given the amounts i used when making mine as a guide - it s a good idea to have a bit more on hand since everyone s knitting style is a little different and you will definitely need more if you decide to make them larger or longer since these mitts use small amounts of several colors they are a great project for using leftover sock or other fingering weight yarns you can make all the flowers the same color or make each row different a self-striping yarn would work great for these the yarns i used were knit picks palette 50g/231yd 100% wool mc celestial leaves edamame flowers safflower serrano sky sweet potato fairy tale instructions note both hands are made the same with a centered thumb so just make two with mc cast on 60 sts distribute on needles according to your preferred method of working join for working in
